title: After 55 years with Claude’s help I tried again to create Simulated Hermaphroditic Evolving Monopoly Players

videos.title: Simulated Hermaphroditic Evolving Monopoly Players demo
Simulated Hermaphroditic Evolving Monopoly Players demo

description: After 55 years, Ken Kahn revisited his ambitious 1969 computer science project: "Simulated Hermaphroditic Evolving Monopoly Players" (SHEMPs). Originally crafted with Algol W and punch cards, SHEMPs explored how virtual Monopoly players could evolve their strategies through simulated "mating" and parameter swapping based on game success. Leveraging Claude's AI capabilities, Kahn endeavored to resurrect and refine this complex evolutionary simulation, aiming to finally test if players could evolve to play better than chance. This modern collaboration with Claude resulted in the "Cosmic Trader" game artifacts, demonstrating AI's potential to breathe new life into intricate, long-abandoned computational ideas and advance evolutionary game theory.

title: Gemini creating a Tetris-like game for foreign language practice

videos.title: WordFall demo - vocabulary practice in a tetris-like game
WordFall demo - vocabulary practice in a tetris-like game

description: This research details how Gemini 2.5 Pro impressively created "WordFall," a unique Tetris-like game designed for foreign language practice. From a single prompt, Gemini rapidly developed a nearly complete web game where users match falling blocks of words from two languages that share the same meaning. The AI iteratively extended the game's functionality, generating word lists for user-defined categories, supporting any two languages, and even navigating complex Chrome AI API integrations. Despite initial challenges with API adoption, Gemini demonstrated remarkable adaptability, ultimately prototyping a sophisticated and interactive educational tool. This project vividly showcases AI's potential to rapidly develop engaging language learning experiences.

title: Co-creating a multi speaker app
description: This research details the fascinating co-creation of a "Multi-Speaker Text-to-Speech Converter" web app, born from the desire to hear a simulated conversation between AI pioneers like Minsky and Turing. Collaborating extensively with Claude and Gemini, the author developed an innovative tool that transforms chat logs into dynamic audio, enabling users to customize each virtual speaker's pitch and rate. The project navigated complex challenges, including generating shareable URLs for unique voice settings and cleverly addressing browser-specific voice inconsistencies by programming the app to find similar alternatives. This engaging exploration ultimately produced a sophisticated application designed to bring historical dialogues to life, with a future enhancement to display contextual web pages alongside each utterance.

title: Chatbots are pretty good at making up believable words
description: This fascinating research explores AI's surprising capacity for linguistic innovation, challenging chatbots to invent new, believable English words. Inspired by Shakespeare's vocabulary contributions, the author prompted ChatGPT, Claude, and Gemini to create ten words, complete with dictionary definitions and sample uses. The results were remarkably creative and often humorous, like ChatGPT's 'glintwist' for a shared unspoken glance or Claude's 'Afterclap' describing an awkward applause moment. The study further investigated if these AI-generated words had existing online matches, revealing a nuanced blend of true novelty and occasional coincidences, showcasing AI's impressive, yet sometimes serendipitous, linguistic prowess.

title: Chatbots helped me explore and understand “Contemplative Artificial Intelligence”
description: This research unveils a novel approach to AI-assisted learning, where the user prompted Claude Artifact and Gemini to *ask them questions* about a paper on "Contemplative Artificial Intelligence." This innovative role-reversal allowed for a profound exploration of how principles like mindfulness, emptiness, and non-duality could shape AI systems towards "Superalignment," preventing runaway optimization and adversarial behaviors. The chatbots offered remarkably constructive feedback, guiding the researcher to a deeper, self-corrected understanding of this complex and vital topic. This method showcases a powerful new paradigm for interactive educational engagement, flipping traditional learning dynamics.

title: Exploring Pythagoras's Theorem with AI help

apps.title: ChatGPT - Pythagoras Intuition – Rearrangement Proof (interactive Svg)
ChatGPT - Pythagoras Intuition – Rearrangement Proof (interactive Svg)
ChatGPT - Pythagoras Intuition – Rearrangement Proof (interactive Svg)
ChatGPT - Pythagoras Intuition – Rearrangement Proof (interactive Svg)

description: This research explores the challenging frontier of using AI to create intuitive, interactive geometric explanations. Focusing on Pythagoras's Theorem, the author meticulously probed various AI models like Claude, ChatGPT, and Gemini to generate interactive SVG rearrangement proofs. Despite initial "laughable" text-to-video outputs and numerous direct SVG generation "failures," the project systematically investigated how prompting for the theorem's *intuition first* could lead to more promising results. The goal was to overcome AI's typical struggles with geometric understanding, ultimately aiming to construct engaging, AI-assisted interactive demonstrations of the theorem's core principles.

title: Chatbots can build an app to “vibe code” micro:bits

videos.title: Using AI to collect and analyze data from a micro:bit
Using AI to collect and analyze data from a micro:bit
Using AI to collect and analyze data from a micro:bit
Using AI to collect and analyze data from a micro:bit
Using AI to collect and analyze data from a micro:bit

description: This research explores the fascinating potential of AI chatbots to create web applications for programming micro:bit computers, enabling functions like "vibe code." While Gemini initially deemed the task infeasible, Claude successfully developed a proof-of-concept app capable of generating micro:bit programs. Although direct USB device connectivity posed a challenge for the AI-generated web app, the project ultimately demonstrated how chatbots could autonomously build and debug micro:bit programs, even creating a two-minute demo to display temperature. This highlights a novel approach to developing interactive educational tools with AI.

title: Claude creates an app for visualizing acceleration data with commentary
description: Veteran AI researcher Ken Kahn leveraged Claude 4.5 to co-create an innovative web app for visualizing micro:bit acceleration data. This interactive 3D tool not only displays movement paths but also features AI-generated commentary. Using the Claude API, the app analyzes the data in real-time to identify complex gestures like circular or back-and-forth motions, providing descriptive subtitles with speed control. This project impressively showcases how AI can transform raw sensor data into rich, understandable insights, amplifying human creativity in educational and analytical contexts.

title: Five personas creating a musical app about Euclid’s primes proof

apps.title: Prime Number Imps in Mid‑Jig, Twirl, and Hop
Prime Number Imps in Mid‑Jig, Twirl, and Hop

description: This research explores an innovative AI collaboration, where five distinct personas—an artist, lyricist, musician, programmer, and beta tester—teamed up to create a musical web app. Their challenge: to transform Euclid’s complex proof of infinite primes into an engaging, funny, and illustrated experience. The project explored integrating AI-generated images, animations, lyrics, and songs, culminating in an app titled "Prime Number Imps." This showcases the potential for AI to collaboratively produce rich, multi-modal educational content.

title: Disappointing chats despite improvements to Gemini multi-persona app
description: This research post details fascinating experiments with a Gemini multi-persona app, where different LLM instances chat to create educational content. The exploration included scenarios like animal personas collaboratively writing a story for elementary students and recreating a historical debate among Aristotle, Galileo, and Newton. Despite receiving "pretty good" persona suggestions from ChatGPT and implementing several app improvements (e.g., image generation, chat tone), the resulting conversations and story drafts proved disappointing, with the famous scientist debate even underperforming an earlier version. However, the researcher remains optimistic about the multi-persona approach's potential to foster student learning, particularly by assigning distinct roles like plot or character development to each AI.

title: Using Claude to create Claude-powered apps
description: This research dives into the innovative process of leveraging Claude to build and host its own AI-powered web applications, dubbed "Artifacts." The author discovered a game-changing method that eliminates traditional API key complexities and deployment hurdles, making LLM app development and sharing remarkably accessible, even for free Claude users. The primary creation was an animated SVG generator, capable of drawing user-defined images and bringing them to life with growing and spinning effects. While iterative improvements added features like suggested examples, challenges with Claude's code editing required strategic re-prompting to fix bugs and ultimately streamline the functional app. This hands-on exploration vividly demonstrates both the immense potential and practical quirks of using Claude for rapid AI application development.

title: A Claude app to converse with independent Claude personas
description: This research explores a novel Claude app designed for dynamic conversations between independent AI personas. Users define unique personas that interact with each other and the user, fostering complex, multi-agent dialogues. The project ambitiously integrated features like rendering persona-generated SVG images, converting HTML output into interactive code buttons, and enabling AI reactions to user-pasted images. While initial success led to a functional app, the study candidly reveals Claude 4 Sonnet's current limitations in combining such advanced functionalities into a single, robust application, suggesting a threshold for complexity.

title: Updating the Connection Game Maker
description: This research details an evolving project to create AI-powered New York Times-style Connections games. Starting with an initial ChatGPT 4 app, the developer progressively updated the "Connection Game Maker" to leverage Gemini Nano for browser-based functionality, then further integrated both Gemini and Claude APIs, resulting in multiple app versions. A key exploration involved crafting editable prompts that allow users to highly customize puzzles, even generating unique emoji-based games. The post offers a fascinating look into practical LLM application, from API integration and code development challenges to the curious disappearance of a Gemini-created version, hinting at intellectual property considerations.

title: Weird hybrid creature guessing game co-created with Gemini
description: Ken Kahn's research explores Gemini Pro 2.5's app generation capabilities by co-creating a "weird hybrid creature guessing game." This unique web-based game challenges players to identify fantastical cross-breed animals, rendered in the distinctive style of 19th-century naturalist illustrations. Despite initial AI "misunderstandings" about its image generation limits, iterative prompting led Gemini to successfully build the interactive platform, integrating image generation via API with dynamic chat responses. The collaborative process further refined the game with features like guess limits, humorous feedback, and "field notes," showcasing Gemini's potential for developing engaging, multi-modal applications.

title: Chatbots designing and making apps
description: This intriguing research delves into the creative potential of AI chatbots like ChatGPT, Gemini, and Claude, challenging them to autonomously design and implement "unusual fun web app ideas." Researcher Ken Kahn acted as a critical guide, providing feedback such as "improve" or "vary," while the AI models generated the app concepts and code. The experiment yielded 16 diverse applications, including the whimsical "Confetti Compliments App," the imaginative "Word Garden Flowers," and the mystical "Constellation Composer" and "The Alchemist's Grimoire." This study vividly demonstrates the chatbots' surprising ability to not only conceptualize unique, quirky applications but also bring them to life with minimal human intervention, showcasing their unexpected design and development capabilities.

title: A multi-persona app generating storybooks and comic books
description: This research details the creation of a multi-persona app, built with Gemini, designed to transform chat conversations into dynamic visual narratives. The project explored using Gemini's image generation capabilities to automatically create comic books, graphic novels, and children's storybooks from dialogues, depicting speakers and their utterances in illustrated panels. While the process faced challenges with Gemini frequently embedding unwanted text and embellishments, the author iteratively refined the prompting. Ultimately, the children's storybook style proved most successful in visualizing these AI conversations, offering a novel approach to making interactive AI discussions more accessible and engaging through visual storytelling.

title: Seven personas and me talking about creating an app for learning about numbers
description: This research showcases an innovative approach to educational app design, simulating a "team" of seven AI-driven expert personas—including luminaries like Piaget, Papert, and McCulloch—to conceptualize tools for young children's number learning. Through 162 detailed exchanges, the author engaged these virtual experts in designing and iteratively developing working web applications, most notably the "Number Explorer Prototype V3." This unique AI-facilitated conversation, enhanced with a "storybook" mode, offers fascinating insights into how diverse perspectives can shape effective learning technologies for foundational numerical understanding.

title: Playing Tic Tac Toe with a snarky AI
description: This research details the creation of an engaging, web-based Tic-Tac-Toe game where players challenge a "snarky AI." Beginning with a perfect-play engine crafted by ChatGPT, the project quickly evolved. Gemini was integrated to provide humorous, witty remarks with each move, transforming the AI from a mere opponent into a playful, verbal adversary. Further exploration added speech recognition, allowing players to converse directly with the AI, showcasing an iterative development process across multiple LLMs like Gemini and Claude to build truly interactive AI experiences.

title: An app for exploring creativity in chatbots
description: Inspired by research revealing AI's dual impact—boosting individual creativity while reducing collective diversity—this project introduces an innovative app to explore chatbot creativity. The Gemini Response Explorer was developed to conduct 12 focused experiments, systematically manipulating LLM 'temperature' settings and integrating prompts like "Be creative." This hands-on investigation aimed to understand how these variables influence the diversity of AI-generated story summaries, specifically addressing the observed trend of increased output similarity. The findings offer practical insights into generating more varied and less homogenous creative content from large language models.

title: Gemini 2.0 Flash talking to itself
description: This research explores the intriguing realm of multiple Gemini 2.0 Flash AI instances conversing with each other, leveraging its generous free API tier to explore emergent creativity. The project began by tasking one AI to build a web page facilitating these multi-instance discussions, which evolved into a sophisticated conversation app capable of generating graphics and animations from AI interactions. A highlight is the collaboratively designed "Sentient Spoonful (Emoji Edition with Sound)" – a whimsical "soup game" crafted by an "Expert programmer" AI and an "Out-of-the-box thinker" AI. This demonstrates the profound potential for AI models to not only converse, but to autonomously create and innovate, even designing interactive applications.

title: Using “Reasoning” chatbots to improve the Connections Puzzle game generator
description: This research introduces an innovative method for refining LLM prompts, specifically for a "Connections Puzzle" game generator. Instead of solely relying on output, the author leveraged "reasoning" chatbots like ChatGPT o1 and DeepSeek R1 to expose their internal chain of thought. By analyzing their detailed reasoning, hidden prompt ambiguities and misunderstandings became immediately apparent. The author then engaged these models in dialogue to clarify instructions, ultimately tasking them with *improving the prompt itself*. This novel approach offers a powerful way to debug and enhance LLM instructions, moving beyond traditional trial-and-error to create more robust applications.

title: Chatbot-assisted co-creation of a neural net to judge confidence from text
description: This research showcases the iterative, chatbot-assisted co-creation of a neural network designed to judge confidence from text. Beginning as a pre-LLM Snap! model, the project evolved significantly with ChatGPT's help to build a web-based version. Crucially, LLMs like Claude 3.5 were leveraged to dramatically enlarge the training dataset, leading to improved model accuracy. The post highlights how conversational AI tools are invaluable co-creators, offering suggestions for architecture, training, and data generation, making complex machine learning app development more accessible and effective.

title: Experiments with an app to repeat prompts to LLMs
description: Researcher Ken Kahn developed the "Repeating LLM Prompter" app to explore how Large Language Models respond to iterative prompting. This innovative tool feeds LLMs a combination of static text and a dynamic response area, iteratively replacing the dynamic portion with the LLM's latest output. Fascinating experiments, such as repeatedly prompting Gemini to "improve" Shakespeare's "To be, or not to be," revealed how LLMs can progressively expand and poeticize text over many turns. This research offers a unique glimpse into an LLM's capacity for sustained creative refinement, showcasing the potential of iterative prompting for deep textual exploration.

title: ChatGPT 4o creates a Chrome extension to find the contextual meaning of words on web pages
description: This research showcases ChatGPT 4o's remarkable ability to create a functional Chrome extension designed to find the contextual meaning of words on web pages. Users can simply select a word, right-click, and instantly receive a precise definition tailored to its specific usage within the sentence. What's truly impressive is that ChatGPT 4o generated every single line of code, from the initial plan to the final refined version, after being prompted with the forthcoming Gemini Nano API documentation. This innovative tool, running locally and offline, demonstrates the power of LLMs to provide nuanced linguistic assistance. The entire process, completed in just a few hours, highlights AI's burgeoning capability in rapid, autonomous software development.

title: Playing chess by flipping between a ChatGPT tab and a chess app
description: This research explores automating the interactive experience of playing chess against a chatbot. Initially, ChatGPT 4o was tasked with creating a web app that displayed a chess board and allowed drag-and-drop moves, converting them into standard notation. The core innovation, however, involved leveraging Claude 3.5 to develop a sophisticated Chrome extension. This extension masterfully automates the tedious copy-pasting of moves between the custom chess app and the chatbot tab. The project compellingly demonstrates AI's capability to not only generate functional applications but also to build intelligent tools that bridge digital interfaces, significantly enhancing user engagement and streamlining complex interactions.

title: Dialog and OceanAI responses and generated games by Claude 3
description: Breaking from traditional AI research, this post unveils a fascinating experiment where Claude 3.5 Sonnet was tasked with a dual role: simulating two middle school students *and* iteratively generating a web game based on their simulated conversations. The outcome is a 24-page illustrated story, "EcoQuest," chronicling Zoe and Alex's journey to create a simple, environmentally-themed platformer. Claude masterfully produced both the student dialogs and progressive game versions, with ChatGPT 4o generating the accompanying illustrations. This unique exploration powerfully demonstrates AI's capacity to not only assist in app development but also to simulate the user experience and iterative design process, offering profound insights into AI-supported learning.
